item.title: Instead of doing w\e.add over and over
item.dc:creator: @ilyaostr9 io9
item.description:
@ilyaostr9 wrote:

for(Button b : buttons) { buttonAdd(b); }

Which would read as: for each Button in the array buttons, let b represent a member of that array.

With every iteration in the loop, b would represent the next button. In essence, this type of loop is the same as

for(int i = o; i < buttons.length; i++) { Button b = buttons[i]; buttonAdd(b); }
Did that help you understand those loops?

Yz85Racer:

how you put it there because it’s like your room.

Hmm his room is a dumpster, and his code is shit? I like the analogy!

Read full topic

item.title: Instead of doing w\e.add over and over
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

[quote=“Frell, post:12, topic:211809”]Looked in the SIDE source and found something like what your explaining:

  String[] menuTitles = {"File", "Text Editor", "Panels", "Configuration", "Help"};
            String[][] menuContent = {{"New Project", "Quick Project", "Open Project", "-", "Garbage Collect", "-", "Quit"},
                    {"New File", "Open File", "-", "Save File", "Save All Files", "-", "Close File", "Close All Files"},
                    {"Hide Console", "Show Console", "-", "Hide Editor", "Show Editor"},
                    {"Edit MainClass", "Edit Parameters", "Edit ClassPath", "Edit Jar Settings"},
                    {"Info", "Website", "Forums", "Version"}};
            JMenuBar menuBar = makeMenuBar(menuTitles, menuContent);

Dont know if it will help.[/quote]Well, uhhhh, perhaps if umm, you showed the makeMenuBar method, which is really simple.

If someone would just explain the for-each loop…

Basically, for-each takes an array, and puts it into objects.

So say:

int[] integerArray = new int[] { 1, 2, 3 };
// There is your array. Now lets loop it…:
for (int i : integerArray) {
System.out.println(i);
}
// Output:
// 1
// 2
// 3

It takes all of the items in the array, piece by piece, and assigns it to the variable ‘i’.
Then you can use the variable as you’d like.

Read full topic

  String[] menuTitles = {"File", "Text Editor", "Panels", "Configuration", "Help"};
            String[][] menuContent = {{"New Project", "Quick Project", "Open Project", "-", "Garbage Collect", "-", "Quit"},
                    {"New File", "Open File", "-", "Save File", "Save All Files", "-", "Close File", "Close All Files"},
                    {"Hide Console", "Show Console", "-", "Hide Editor", "Show Editor"},
                    {"Edit MainClass", "Edit Parameters", "Edit ClassPath", "Edit Jar Settings"},
                    {"Info", "Website", "Forums", "Version"}};
            JMenuBar menuBar = makeMenuBar(menuTitles, menuContent);

Dont know if it will help.

item.title: Instead of doing w\e.add over and over
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

[quote=“TeleNubby, post:10, topic:211809”]The only add() method I see with three parameters is:
http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.4.2/docs/api/java/awt/Container.html#add(java.awt.Component,%20java.lang.Object,%20int)

Which I doubt is what you’re trying to use it for. You cant just use a method with the same name and assume it to do exactly that.[/quote]
Frell can!
